definition.name: City Watch / Investigator
definition.description:
You have served the community where you grew up, standing as its first line of defense against crime. You aren’t a soldier, directing your gaze outward at possible enemies. Instead, your service to your hometown was to help police its populace, protecting the citizenry from lawbreakers and malefactors of every stripe.

You might have been part of the City Watch of Waterdeep, the baton-wielding police force of the City of Splendors, protecting the common folk from thieves and rowdy nobility alike. Or you might have been one of the valiant defenders of Silverymoon, a member of the Silverwatch or even one of the magic-wielding Spellguard.

Perhaps you hail from Neverwinter and have served as one of its Wintershield watchmen, the newly founded branch of guards who vow to keep safe the City of Skilled Hands.

Even if you’re not city-born or city-bred, this background can describe your early years as a member of law enforcement. Most settlements of any size have their own constables and police forces, and even smaller communities have sheriffs and bailiffs who stand ready to protect their community.

 

Skill Proficiencies: Athletics, Insight
Languages: Two of your choice
Equipment: A uniform in the style of your unit and indicative of your rank, a horn with which to summon help, a set of manacles, and a pouch containing 10 gp

 

FEATURE: WATCHER'S EYE

Your experience in enforcing the law, and dealing with lawbreakers, gives you a feel for local laws and criminals. You can easily find the local outpost of the watch or a similar organization, and just as easily pick out the dens of criminal activity in a community, although you’re more likely to be welcome in the former locations rather than the latter.

 
Variant: Investigator

Rarer than watch or patrol members are a community’s investigators, who are responsible for solving crimes after the fact. Though such folk are seldom found in rural areas, nearly every settlement of decent size has at least one or two watch members who have the skill to investigate crime scenes and track down criminals. If your prior experience is as an investigator, you have proficiency in Investigation rather than Athletics.

 
Suggested Characteristics

Use the tables for the soldier background below as the basis for your traits and motivations, modifying the entries when appropriate to suit your identity as a member of the city watch.

Your bond is likely associated with your fellow watch members or the watch organization itself and almost certainly concerns your community. Your ideal probably involves the fostering of peace and safety. An investigator is likely to have an ideal connected to achieving justice by successfully solving crimes.

 
Soldier
d8 Personality Trait
1 I’m always polite and respectful.
2 I’m haunted by memories of war. I can’t get the images of violence out of my mind.
3 I’ve lost too many friends, and I’m slow to make new ones.
4 I’m full of inspiring and cautionary tales from my military experience relevant to almost every combat situation.
5 I can stare down a hell hound without flinching.
6 I enjoy being strong and like breaking things.
7 I have a crude sense of humor.
8 I face problems head-on. A simple, direct solution is the best path to success.
d6 Ideal
1 Greater Good. Our lot is to lay down our lives in defense of others. (Good)
2 Responsibility. I do what I must and obey just authority. (Lawful)
3 Independence. When people follow orders blindly, they embrace a kind of tyranny. (Chaotic)
4 Might. In life as in war, the stronger force wins. (Evil)
5 Live and Let Live. Ideals aren’t worth killing over or going to war for. (Neutral)
6 Nation. My city, nation, or people are all that matter. (Any)
d6 Bond
1 I would still lay down my life for the people I served with.
2 Someone saved my life on the battlefield. To this day, I will never leave a friend behind.
3 My honor is my life.
4 I’ll never forget the crushing defeat my company suffered or the enemies who dealt it.
5 Those who fight beside me are those worth dying for.
6 I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
d6 Flaw
1 The monstrous enemy we faced in battle still leaves me quivering with fear.
2 I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
3 I made a terrible mistake in battle that cost many lives, and I would do anything to keep that mistake secret.
4 My hatred of my enemies is blind and unreasoning.
5 I obey the law, even if the law causes misery.
6 I’d rather eat my armor than admit when I’m wrong.
definition.shortDescription:
You have served the community where you grew up, standing as its first line of defense against crime. You aren’t a soldier, directing your gaze outward at possible enemies. Instead, your service to your hometown was to help police its populace, protecting the citizenry from lawbreakers and malefactors of every stripe.

You might have been part of the City Watch of Waterdeep, the baton-wielding police force of the City of Splendors, protecting the common folk from thieves and rowdy nobility alike. Or you might have been one of the valiant defenders of Silverymoon, a member of the Silverwatch or even one of the magic-wielding Spellguard.

Perhaps you hail from Neverwinter and have served as one of its Wintershield watchmen, the newly founded branch of guards who vow to keep safe the City of Skilled Hands.

Even if you’re not city-born or city-bred, this background can describe your early years as a member of law enforcement. Most settlements of any size have their own constables and police forces, and even smaller communities have sheriffs and bailiffs who stand ready to protect their community.

You can easily find the local outpost of the watch or a similar organization, and just as easily pick out the dens of criminal activity in a community, although you’re more likely to be welcome in the former locations rather than the latter.

I’ve lost too many friends, and I’m slow to make new ones.
I’m full of inspiring and cautionary tales from my military experience relevant to almost every combat situation.
I can stare down a hell hound without flinching.
I enjoy being strong and like breaking things.
I have a crude sense of humor.
I face problems head-on. A simple, direct solution is the best path to success.

Responsibility. I do what I must and obey just authority. (Lawful)
Independence. When people follow orders blindly, they embrace a kind of tyranny. (Chaotic)

bonds.description: I would still lay down my life for the people I served with.
Someone saved my life on the battlefield. To this day, I will never leave a friend behind.
I’ll never forget the crushing defeat my company suffered or the enemies who dealt it.
Those who fight beside me are those worth dying for.
I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.

flaws.description: The monstrous enemy we faced in battle still leaves me quivering with fear.
I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
I made a terrible mistake in battle that cost many lives, and I would do anything to keep that mistake secret.
My hatred of my enemies is blind and unreasoning.
I obey the law, even if the law causes misery.
I’d rather eat my armor than admit when I’m wrong.

race.description:
Harengons are blessed with a little fey luck, and they often find themselves a few fortunate feet away from dangers during adventures.

Racial Traits
Hare-Trigger, Leporine Senses, Lucky Footwork, Rabbit Hop

definition.name: Creature Type
definition.description: You are a Humanoid.
definition.snippet: You are a Humanoid.

definition.name: Speed
definition.description: Your walking speed is 30 feet.
definition.snippet: Your walking speed is 30 ft.

definition.name: Hare-Trigger
definition.description: You can add your proficiency bonus to your initiative rolls.
definition.snippet: You can add your proficiency bonus ({{proficiency}}) to your initiative rolls.

definition.name: Leporine Senses
definition.description: You have proficiency in the Perception skill.
definition.snippet: You have proficiency in the Perception skill.

definition.name: Lucky Footwork
definition.description: When you fail a Dexterity saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll a d4 and add it to the save, potentially turning the failure into a success. You can’t use this reaction if you’re prone or your speed is 0.
definition.snippet: When you fail a DEX saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll a d4 and add it to the save, potentially turning the failure into a success. You can’t use this reaction if you’re prone or your speed is 0.

definition.name: Rabbit Hop
definition.description: As a bonus action, you can jump a number of feet equal to five times your proficiency bonus, without provoking opportunity attacks. You can use this trait only if your speed is greater than 0. You can use it a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
definition.snippet: As a bonus action, you can jump {{5*proficiency#unsigned}} ft. without provoking opportunity attacks. You can only use this trait if your speed is greater than 0. You can use it {{proficiency#unsigned}} times and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

definition.name: Size
definition.description: You are Medium or Small. You choose the size when you select this race.
definition.snippet: You are Medium or Small. You choose the size when you select this race.

definition.name: Ability Score Increases
definition.description: When determining your character’s ability scores, increase one score by 2 and increase a different score by 1, or increase three different scores by 1. Follow this rule regardless of the method you use to determine the scores, such as rolling or point buy. The “Quick Build” section for your character’s class offers suggestions on which scores to increase. You can follow those suggestions or ignore them, but you can’t raise any of your scores above 20.
definition.snippet: When determining your character’s ability scores, increase one score by 2 and increase a different score by 1, or increase three different scores by 1.

definition.name: Languages
definition.description: Your character can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for the character. The Player’s Handbook offers a list of languages to choose from. The DM is free to modify that list for a campaign.
definition.snippet: Your character can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for the character.

notes.otherNotes: First come smiles, then lies, then arrows!

traits.personalityTraits:
I’m always polite and respectful.
I enjoy being strong and like breaking things.
traits.ideals: Independence. When people follow orders blindly, they embrace a kind of tyranny. (Chaotic)
traits.bonds: I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
traits.flaws: My hatred of my enemies is blind and unreasoning.

definition.name: Chain Mail
definition.description: Made of interlocking metal rings, chain mail includes a layer of quilted fabric worn underneath the mail to prevent chafing and to cushion the impact of blows. The suit includes gauntlets.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description: Proficiency with a dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description: Proficiency with a dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Rapier
definition.description: Proficiency with a rapier allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

definition.name: Longbow
definition.description: Proficiency with a longbow allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Ammunition
properties.description:
You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield. 
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon (see "Improvised Weapons" later in the section). A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

properties.name: Heavy
properties.description: Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

properties.name: Range
properties.description: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's long range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

properties.name: Two-Handed
properties.description: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

definition.name: Backpack
definition.description:
A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.

definition.name: Bedroll
definition.description: You never know where you’re going to sleep, and a bedroll helps you get better sleep in a hayloft or on the cold ground. A bedroll consists of bedding and a blanket thin enough to be rolled up and tied. In an emergency, it can double as a stretcher.

definition.name: Mess Kit
definition.description: This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.

definition.name: Rations (1 day)
definition.description: Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.

definition.name: Rope, Hempen (50 feet)
definition.description: Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

definition.name: Tinderbox
definition.description: This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch -- or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel -- takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

definition.name: Torch
definition.description: A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.

definition.name: Waterskin
definition.description: A waterskin can hold 4 pints of liquid.

definition.name: Fighter
definition.description:
A master of martial combat, skilled with a variety of weapons and armor

Hit Die: d10
Primary Ability: Strength or Dexterity
Saves: Strength & Constitution
definition.equipmentDescription:
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) chain mail or (b) leather armor, longbow, and 20 arrows
  • (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons
  • (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) two handaxes
  • (a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack

classFeatures.name: Fighting Style
classFeatures.description: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

classFeatures.name: Second Wind
classFeatures.description: You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your fighter level. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

classFeatures.name: Action Surge
classFeatures.description:
Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits for a moment. On your turn, you can take one additional action.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest, but only once on the same turn.

classFeatures.name: Martial Archetype
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate in your combat styles and techniques. Choose Champion, Battle Master, or Eldritch Knight, all detailed at the end of the class description. The archetype you choose grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

classFeatures.name: Indomitable
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level and three times between long rests starting at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 6th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 14th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 11th level, you can attack three times, instead of twice, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description: At 20th level, you can attack four times, instead of three, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: All armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two skills from Acrobatics, Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, and Survival

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d10 per fighter level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per fighter level after 1st

subclassDefinition.name: Arcane Archer
subclassDefinition.description: An Arcane Archer studies a unique elven method of archery that weaves magic into attacks to produce supernatural effects. Arcane Archers are some of the most elite warriors among the elves. They stand watch over the fringes of elven domains, keeping a keen eye out for trespassers and using magic-infused arrows to defeat monsters and invaders before they can reach elven settlements. Over the centuries, the methods of these elf archers have been learned by members of other races who can also balance arcane aptitude with archery.

classFeatures.name: Arcane Archer Lore
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you learn magical theory or some of the secrets of nature — typical for practitioners of this elven martial tradition. You choose to gain proficiency in either the Arcana or the Nature skill, and you choose to learn either the prestidigitation or the druidcraft cantrip.

classFeatures.name: Arcane Shot
classFeatures.description:
At 3rd level, you learn to unleash special magical effects with some of your shots. When you gain this feature, you learn two Arcane Shot options of your choice (see “Arcane Shot Options” below).

Once per turn when you fire an arrow from a shortbow or longbow as part of the Attack action, you can apply one of your Arcane Shot options to that arrow. You decide to use the option when the arrow hits a creature, unless the option doesn’t involve an attack roll. You have two uses of this ability, and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a short or long rest.

You gain an additional Arcane Shot option of your choice when you reach certain levels in this class: 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level. Each option also improves when you become an 18th-level fighter.

classFeatures.name: Magic Arrow
classFeatures.description: At 7th level, you gain the ability to infuse arrows with magic. Whenever you fire a nonmagical arrow from a shortbow or longbow, you can make it magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. The magic fades from the arrow immediately after it hits or misses its target.

classFeatures.name: Curving Shot
classFeatures.description: At 7th level, you learn how to direct an errant arrow toward a new target. When you make an attack roll with a magic arrow and miss, you can use a bonus action to reroll the attack roll against a different target within 60 feet of the original target.

classFeatures.name: Ever-Ready Shot
classFeatures.description: Starting at 15th level, your magical archery is available whenever battle starts. If you roll initiative and have no uses of Arcane Shot remaining, you regain one use of it.

classFeatures.name: Arcane Shot Options
classFeatures.description:
The Arcane Shot feature lets you choose options for it at certain levels. The options are presented here in alphabetical order. They are all magical effects, and each one is associated with one of the schools of magic.

If an option requires a saving throw, your Arcane Shot save DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier.

classFeatures.name: Fighting Style
classFeatures.description: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

classFeatures.name: Second Wind
classFeatures.description: You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your fighter level. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

classFeatures.name: Action Surge
classFeatures.description:
Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits for a moment. On your turn, you can take one additional action.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest, but only once on the same turn.

classFeatures.name: Martial Archetype
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate in your combat styles and techniques. Choose Champion, Battle Master, or Eldritch Knight, all detailed at the end of the class description. The archetype you choose grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

classFeatures.name: Indomitable
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level and three times between long rests starting at 17th level.

classFeatures.description:
When you reach 6th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 11th level, you can attack three times, instead of twice, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description: At 20th level, you can attack four times, instead of three, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: All armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two skills from Acrobatics, Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, and Survival

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d10 per fighter level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per fighter level after 1st

definition.name: Arcane Archer Lore
definition.description: At 3rd level, you learn magical theory or some of the secrets of nature — typical for practitioners of this elven martial tradition. You choose to gain proficiency in either the Arcana or the Nature skill, and you choose to learn either the prestidigitation or the druidcraft cantrip.
definition.snippet: You gain proficiency in an additional skill and learn an additional cantrip.

definition.name: Arcane Shot
definition.description:
At 3rd level, you learn to unleash special magical effects with some of your shots. When you gain this feature, you learn two Arcane Shot options of your choice (see “Arcane Shot Options” below).

Once per turn when you fire an arrow from a shortbow or longbow as part of the Attack action, you can apply one of your Arcane Shot options to that arrow. You decide to use the option when the arrow hits a creature, unless the option doesn’t involve an attack roll. You have two uses of this ability, and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a short or long rest.

You gain an additional Arcane Shot option of your choice when you reach certain levels in this class: 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level. Each option also improves when you become an 18th-level fighter.
definition.snippet: Twice per short rest and once per turn when you fire an arrow from a shortbow or longbow as part of the Attack action, you can apply one Arcane Shot option of your choice to that arrow. You decide to use the option when the arrow hits a creature, unless the option doesn’t involve an attack roll.

definition.name: Magic Arrow
definition.description: At 7th level, you gain the ability to infuse arrows with magic. Whenever you fire a nonmagical arrow from a shortbow or longbow, you can make it magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. The magic fades from the arrow immediately after it hits or misses its target.
definition.snippet: Whenever you fire a nonmagical arrow from a shortbow or longbow, you can make it magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity, but the magic fades from the arrow on a hit or miss.

definition.name: Curving Shot
definition.description: At 7th level, you learn how to direct an errant arrow toward a new target. When you make an attack roll with a magic arrow and miss, you can use a bonus action to reroll the attack roll against a different target within 60 feet of the original target.
definition.snippet: When you make an attack roll with a magic arrow and miss, you can use a bonus action to reroll the attack roll against a different target within 60 ft. of the original target.

definition.name: Ever-Ready Shot
definition.description: Starting at 15th level, your magical archery is available whenever battle starts. If you roll initiative and have no uses of Arcane Shot remaining, you regain one use of it.
definition.snippet: If you roll initiative and have no uses of Arcane Shot remaining, you regain one use of it.

definition.name: Arcane Shot Options
definition.description:
The Arcane Shot feature lets you choose options for it at certain levels. The options are presented here in alphabetical order. They are all magical effects, and each one is associated with one of the schools of magic.

If an option requires a saving throw, your Arcane Shot save DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier.

definition.name: Fighting Style
definition.description: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.
definition.snippet: You adopt a fighting style specialty.

definition.name: Second Wind
definition.description: You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your fighter level. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.
definition.snippet: Once per short rest, you can use a bonus action to regain 1d10 + {{classlevel}} HP.

definition.name: Action Surge
definition.description:
Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits for a moment. On your turn, you can take one additional action.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest, but only once on the same turn.
definition.snippet: You can take one additional action on your turn. This can be used {{scalevalue}} times per short rest.

definition.name: Martial Archetype
definition.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you strive to emulate in your combat styles and techniques. Choose Champion, Battle Master, or Eldritch Knight, all detailed at the end of the class description. The archetype you choose grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Extra Attack
definition.description:
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.
definition.snippet: You can attack twice whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.multiClassDescription:
This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

definition.name: Indomitable
definition.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level and three times between long rests starting at 17th level.
definition.snippet: You can reroll a saving throw that you fail - you must use the new roll. You can use this {{scalevalue}} times per long rest.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 6th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 14th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Extra Attack
definition.description:
Beginning at 11th level, you can attack three times, instead of twice, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

The number of attacks increases to four when you reach 20th level in this class.
definition.snippet: You can attack three times whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.multiClassDescription: This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

definition.name: Extra Attack
definition.description: At 20th level, you can attack four times, instead of three, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.snippet: You can attack four times whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.multiClassDescription: This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

definition.name: Proficiencies
definition.description:
Armor: All armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two skills from Acrobatics, Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, and Survival
definition.multiClassDescription:
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons

definition.name: Hit Points
definition.description:
Hit Dice: 1d10 per fighter level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per fighter level after 1st

customActions.name: Bless
customActions.description: Whenever I make an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, I can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the attack roll or saving throw.

definition.name: Druidcraft
definition.description:
Whispering to the spirits of nature, you create one of the following effects within range:

  • You create a tiny, harmless sensory effect that predicts what the weather will be at your location for the next 24 hours. The effect might manifest as a golden orb for clear skies, a cloud for rain, falling snowflakes for snow, and so on. This effect persists for 1 round.
  • You instantly make a flower blossom, a seed pod open, or a leaf bud bloom.
  • You create an instantaneous, harmless sensory effect, such as falling leaves, a puff of wind, the sound of a small animal, or the faint odor of skunk. The effect must fit in a 5-foot cube.
  • You instantly light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a small campfire.

definition.name: Increase two scores (+2 / +1)
definition.description: Increase one score by 2 and increase a different score by 1.
definition.snippet: Increase one of these scores by 2 and a different score by 1.

definition.name: Archery
definition.description: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.
definition.snippet: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

definition.name: Grasping Arrow
definition.description:
When this arrow strikes its target, conjuration magic creates grasping, poisonous brambles, which wrap around the target. The creature hit by the arrow takes an extra 2d6 poison damage, its speed is reduced by 10 feet, and it takes 2d6 slashing damage the first time on each turn it moves 1 foot or more without teleporting. The target or any creature that can reach it can use its action to remove the brambles with a successful Strength (Athletics) check against your Arcane Shot save DC. Otherwise, the brambles last for 1 minute or until you use this option again.

The poison damage and slashing damage both increase to 4d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.
definition.snippet: A creature hit by the arrow takes an extra {{(classlevel/18)@rounddown*2+2}}d6 poison damage, its speed is reduced by 10 ft., and it takes {{(classlevel/18)@rounddown*2+2}}d6 slashing damage the first time on each turn it moves 1 ft. or more. The brambles last for 1 minute, until you use this option again, or until any creature uses an action to remove them with an Athletics check (DC {{savedc:int}}).

definition.name: Banishing Arrow
definition.description:
You use abjuration magic to try to temporarily banish your target to a harmless location in the Feywild. The creature hit by the arrow must also succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be banished. While banished in this way, the target’s speed is 0, and it is incapacitated. At the end of its next turn, the target reappears in the space it vacated or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

After you reach 18th level in this class, a target also takes 2d6 force damage when the arrow hits it.
definition.snippet: A creature hit by your arrow must also succeed on a CHA saving throw (DC {{savedc:int}}) or be banished. While banished, the target’s speed is 0, and it is incapacitated. At the end of its next turn, the target reappears in the space it vacated or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied. [18th] +2d6 force damage on hit

race.label: Choose an Ability Score to increase by 2
Choose an Ability Score to increase by 1

class.label: Choose an Arcane Archer Lore Skill

options.label: Defense
options.description: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

options.label: Dueling
options.description: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

options.label: Great Weapon Fighting
options.description: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2. The weapon must have the two-handed or versatile property for you to gain this benefit.

options.label: Protection
options.description: When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll. You must be wielding a shield.

options.label: Two-Weapon Fighting
options.description: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

options.label: Blind Fighting
options.description: You have blindsight with a range of 10 feet. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn’t behind total cover, even if you’re blinded or in darkness. Moreover, you can see an invisible creature within that range, unless the creature successfully hides from you.

options.label: Interception
options.description: When a creature you can see hits a target, other than you, within 5 feet of you with an attack, you can use your reaction to reduce the damage the target takes by 1d10 + your proficiency bonus (to a minimum of 0 damage). You must be wielding a shield or a simple or martial weapon to use this reaction.

options.label: Superior Technique
options.description:
You learn one maneuver of your choice from among those available to the Battle Master archetype. If a maneuver you use requires your target to make a saving throw to resist the maneuver’s effects, the saving throw DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice).

You gain one superiority die, which is a d6 (this die is added to any superiority dice you have from another source). This die is used to fuel your maneuvers. A superiority die is expended when you use it. You regain your expended superiority dice when you finish a short or long rest.

options.label: Thrown Weapon Fighting
options.description:
You can draw a weapon that has the thrown property as part of the attack you make with the weapon.

In addition, when you hit with a ranged attack using a thrown weapon, you gain a +2 bonus to the damage roll.

options.label: Unarmed Fighting
options.description:
Your unarmed strikes can deal bludgeoning damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier on a hit. If you aren’t wielding any weapons or a shield when you make the attack roll, the d6 becomes a d8.

At the start of each of your turns, you can deal 1d4 bludgeoning damage to one creature grappled by you.

options.label: Archery
options.description: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

options.label: Beguiling Arrow
options.description:
Your enchantment magic causes this arrow to temporarily beguile its target. The creature hit by the arrow takes an extra 2d6 psychic damage, and choose one of your allies within 30 feet of the target. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw, or it is charmed by the chosen ally until the start of your next turn. This effect ends early if the chosen ally attacks the charmed target, deals damage to it, or forces it to make a saving throw.

The psychic damage increases to 4d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.

options.label: Bursting Arrow
options.description:
You imbue your arrow with force energy drawn from the school of evocation. The energy detonates after your attack. Immediately after the arrow hits the creature, the target and all other creatures within 10 feet of it take 2d6 force damage each.

The force damage increases to 4d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.

options.label: Enfeebling Arrow
options.description:
You weave necromantic magic into your arrow. The creature hit by the arrow takes an extra 2d6 necrotic damage. The target must also succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or the damage dealt by its weapon attacks is halved until the start of your next turn.

The necrotic damage increases to 4d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.

options.label: Piercing Arrow
options.description:
You use transmutation magic to give your arrow an ethereal quality. When you use this option, you don’t make an attack roll for the attack. Instead, the arrow shoots forward in a line, which is 1 foot wide and 30 feet long, before disappearing. The arrow passes harmlessly through objects, ignoring cover. Each creature in that line must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes damage as if it were hit by the arrow, plus an extra 1d6 piercing damage. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.

The piercing damage increases to 2d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.

options.label: Seeking Arrow
options.description:
Using divination magic, you grant your arrow the ability to seek out a target. When you use this option, you don’t make an attack roll for the attack. Instead, choose one creature you have seen in the past minute. The arrow flies toward that creature, moving around corners if necessary and ignoring three-quarters cover and half cover. If the target is within the weapon’s range and there is a path large enough for the arrow to travel to the target, the target must make a Dexterity saving throw. Otherwise, the arrow disappears after traveling as far as it can. On a failed save, the target takes damage as if it were hit by the arrow, plus an extra 1d6 force damage, and you learn the target’s current location. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage, and you don’t learn its location.

The force damage increases to 2d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.

options.label: Shadow Arrow
options.description:
You weave illusion magic into your arrow, causing it to occlude your foe’s vision with shadows. The creature hit by the arrow takes an extra 2d6 psychic damage, and it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be unable to see anything farther than 5 feet away until the start of your next turn.

The psychic damage increases to 4d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.

options.label: Grasping Arrow
options.description:
When this arrow strikes its target, conjuration magic creates grasping, poisonous brambles, which wrap around the target. The creature hit by the arrow takes an extra 2d6 poison damage, its speed is reduced by 10 feet, and it takes 2d6 slashing damage the first time on each turn it moves 1 foot or more without teleporting. The target or any creature that can reach it can use its action to remove the brambles with a successful Strength (Athletics) check against your Arcane Shot save DC. Otherwise, the brambles last for 1 minute or until you use this option again.

The poison damage and slashing damage both increase to 4d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.

options.label: Banishing Arrow
options.description:
You use abjuration magic to try to temporarily banish your target to a harmless location in the Feywild. The creature hit by the arrow must also succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be banished. While banished in this way, the target’s speed is 0, and it is incapacitated. At the end of its next turn, the target reappears in the space it vacated or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

After you reach 18th level in this class, a target also takes 2d6 force damage when the arrow hits it.

options.label: Druidcraft
options.description:
Whispering to the spirits of nature, you create one of the following effects within range:

  • You create a tiny, harmless sensory effect that predicts what the weather will be at your location for the next 24 hours. The effect might manifest as a golden orb for clear skies, a cloud for rain, falling snowflakes for snow, and so on. This effect persists for 1 round.
  • You instantly make a flower blossom, a seed pod open, or a leaf bud bloom.
  • You create an instantaneous, harmless sensory effect, such as falling leaves, a puff of wind, the sound of a small animal, or the faint odor of skunk. The effect must fit in a 5-foot cube.
  • You instantly light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a small campfire.

options.label: Prestidigitation
options.description:
This spell is a minor magical trick that novice spellcasters use for practice. You create one of the following magical effects within range:

  • You create an instantaneous, harmless sensory effect, such as a shower of sparks, a puff of wind, faint musical notes, or an odd odor.
  • You instantaneously light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a small campfire.
  • You instantaneously clean or soil an object no larger than 1 cubic foot.
  • You chill, warm, or flavor up to 1 cubic foot of nonliving material for 1 hour.
  • You make a color, a small mark, or a symbol appear on an object or a surface for 1 hour.
  • You create a nonmagical trinket or an illusory image that can fit in your hand and that lasts until the end of your next turn.


If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to three of its non-instantaneous effects active at a time, and you can dismiss such an effect as an action.

options.label: Increase three scores (+1 / +1 / +1)
options.description: Increase three different scores by 1.

options.label: Increase two scores (+2 / +1)
options.description: Increase one score by 2 and increase a different score by 1.

race.name: Lucky Footwork
race.description: When you fail a Dexterity saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll a d4 and add it to the save, potentially turning the failure into a success. You can’t use this reaction if you’re [condition]prone[/condition] or your speed is 0.
race.snippet: When you fail a DEX saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll a d4 and add it to the save, potentially turning the failure into a success. You can’t use this reaction if you’re prone or your speed is 0.

race.name: Rabbit Hop
race.description: As a bonus action, you can jump a number of feet equal to five times your proficiency bonus, without provoking opportunity attacks. You can use this trait only if your speed is greater than 0. You can use it a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
race.snippet: As a bonus action, you can jump {{5*proficiency#unsigned}} ft. without provoking opportunity attacks. You can only use this trait if your speed is greater than 0. You can use it {{proficiency#unsigned}} times and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

class.name: Second Wind
class.snippet: Once per short rest, you can use a bonus action to regain 1d10 + {{classlevel}} HP.

class.name: Action Surge
class.snippet: You can take one additional action on your turn. This can be used {{scalevalue}} times per short rest.

class.name: Arcane Shot
class.snippet: Twice per short rest and once per turn when you fire an arrow from a shortbow or longbow as part of the Attack action, you can apply one Arcane Shot option of your choice to that arrow. You decide to use the option when the arrow hits a creature, unless the option doesn’t involve an attack roll.

class.name: Grasping Arrow
class.description:
When this arrow strikes its target, conjuration magic creates grasping, poisonous brambles, which wrap around the target. The creature hit by the arrow takes an extra 2d6 poison damage, its speed is reduced by 10 feet, and it takes 2d6 slashing damage the first time on each turn it moves 1 foot or more without teleporting. The target or any creature that can reach it can use its action to remove the brambles with a successful Strength ([skill]Athletics[/skill]) check against your Arcane Shot save DC. Otherwise, the brambles last for 1 minute or until you use this option again.

The poison damage and slashing damage both increase to 4d6 when you reach 18th level in this class.
class.snippet: A creature hit by the arrow takes an extra {{(classlevel/18)@rounddown*2+2}}d6 poison damage, its speed is reduced by 10 ft., and it takes {{(classlevel/18)@rounddown*2+2}}d6 slashing damage the first time on each turn it moves 1 ft. or more. The brambles last for 1 minute, until you use this option again, or until any creature uses an action to remove them with an Athletics check (DC {{savedc:int}}).

class.name: Banishing Arrow
class.description:
You use abjuration magic to try to temporarily banish your target to a harmless location in the Feywild. The creature hit by the arrow must also succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be banished. While banished in this way, the target’s speed is 0, and it is [condition]incapacitated[/condition]. At the end of its next turn, the target reappears in the space it vacated or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

After you reach 18th level in this class, a target also takes 2d6 force damage when the arrow hits it.
class.snippet: A creature hit by your arrow must also succeed on a CHA saving throw (DC {{savedc:int}}) or be banished. While banished, the target’s speed is 0, and it is incapacitated. At the end of its next turn, the target reappears in the space it vacated or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied. [18th] +2d6 force damage on hit
class.saveFailDescription: The target is banished. While banished, the target’s speed is 0, and it is incapacitated. At the end of its next turn, the target reappears in the space it vacated or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

campaign.name: Wednesday Spelljamming
campaign.description:
Campaign Pitch

Welcome to Spelljammer Academy! Promising recruits are trained here under the tutelage of experienced spelljammers, who prepare fledgling spacefarers for the perils of Wildspace and the Astral Sea. Cadets learn the finer points of ship-to-ship combat, space exploration, and (in some cases) clandestine operations. The newest batch of recruits has just arrived after a long, arduous sea voyage, but there’s still much to do!

Spelljamming 101

  • You may have heard some wild and fanciful stories about Spelljammers and their adventures but most seem too far fetched to be true.
  • Other than hearsay and rumors not much is known about spelljamming by the general population. Too many people are focused on the troubles of their local area to concern themselves with the problems of the stars.
  • One common thread that is widely known is that Spelljamming is the act of using a spelljamming helm to propel and maneuver a ship. The individual that operates the helm is called a spelljammer. Only a select few know what a spelljamming helm is or what it looks like
 VOLUNTEERS WANTED!
All the characters have volunteered, for whatever reason, to join Spelljammer Academy: a shadowy enclave of spellcasters and swords-for-hire situated on the remote and mysterious island of Nimbral.

 

Character Options and House Rules

CHARACTER CREATION

  • Characters begin at 1st level. We’ll be using Milestone leveling for the campaign.
  • Ability scores are determined by rolling 4d6 and dropping the lowest number (re-roll all 1s). You can use the “Customizing Your Origin” feature from Tasha’s Cauldron of Everything to redistribute ability bonuses.
  • You can choose character options from any officially licensed WOTC D&D product excluding, Rick and Morty and Noncore D&D Content. I allow variant races. Please start your character with Class Equipment. Any homebrew items, spells, etc. must be approved by the DM prior to their inclusion in the game.
    • If using DnD Beyond make sure to uncheck the “Homebrew”, “Rick and Morty” and “Non Core” boxes before beginning character creation
  • You are strongly encouraged to choose races that are native to the material plane of Toril as this adventure assumes your character has little to no knowledge of Spelljamming.
    • If your Character is one of the races contained in Spelljammer products, they will be considered natives of Toril for the purposes of this adventure so adjust your backstory accordingly.
    • The two character backgrounds featured in the Spelljammer Astral Adventurer’s Guide (Astral Drifter and Wildspacer) are not available for use for the reason stated above.
    • While the characters are still encouraged to develop backstories, they should be looking for adventure with few long-term bonds to tie them to their homelands. The campaign takes the characters to the stars and beyond, and there might be no coming back afterward!
    • Use the following template below as a primer when asked to give a brief description of your character.
      • Why have you joined Spelljammer Academy?
      • Short physical description of your character. (2-3 sentences)
      • How would you answer a new aquaintance who asks: Where are you from and how'd you wind up in Spelljammer Academy? (2-3 sentences)
      • Five adjectives that describe your character; things that others would pick up after having a coffee or drink with you at a bar.
    • It is assumed that you do not know each other before the campaign starts unless your specific backstory deems it necessary. Each of you volunteered to join the Spelljammer Academy for whatever reason you decide despite not knowing exactly what they do or what exactly spelljamming is.

 House Rules

  • I will not be incorporating any OneD&D play test material in this adventure.
  • The game will follow “Rules as Written” however, I like to empower my players and very much subscribe to the “rule of cool” but be prepared to sell me on your ideas. As your DM I feel I am obligated to clearly explain why I might deny something. In return I expect you be prepared to clearly explain or justify why I should allow you to do something that either bends or breaks the written rules.
  • All rulings are final. However, I encourage my players to engage with me in a private conversation if further discussion is needed. I do not wish to bog down session time with lengthy rules discussions.

Potentially Disturbing Themes - Here’s a list of potentially disturbing themes in this campaign.

  • Gaslighting
  • Illusions and trickery
  • Body horror and gore
  • Kidnapping
  • Child abduction
  • Memory loss
  • Space Clowns
 Lines - This list can be amended at any time by any of the players or DM.
  • physical violence towards children
  • unwanted sexual contact
  • animal abuse or cruelty
  • party-initiated torture
  • Non-consensual inter-party violence
  • inter-party betrayal
  • Suicide
 Veils - This list can be amended at any time by any of the players or DM.
  • ritual sacrifice
  • kidnapping
  • consensual sex
  • enemy-initiated torture
 “Let’s Pause for a Minute” - 

If at any time you don’t feel comfortable with the content or seek clarification of in-game activities out of character, say the phrase “pause for a second” in voice chat and we’ll stop the game, step out of character, and discuss the situation.

Campaign Inspiration

1980 Film - Flash Gordon
